# List of popes

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic
Church"). For popes of the Coptic Orthodox Church, see [List of Coptic
Orthodox Popes of
Alexandria](/wiki/List_of_Coptic_Orthodox_Popes_of_Alexandria "List of Coptic
Orthodox Popes of Alexandria"). For popes of the Legio Maria, see [List of
Legio Maria Popes](/wiki/List_of_Legio_Maria_Popes "List of Legio Maria
Popes"). For Palmarian popes, see [Palmarian Catholic Church §
Popes](/wiki/Palmarian_Catholic_Church#Popes "Palmarian Catholic Church"). For
a graphical representation of this list, see [List of Popes
(graphical)](/wiki/List_of_Popes_\(graphical\) "List of Popes \(graphical\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tafel_paepste.jpg/220px-
Tafel_paepste.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tafel_paepste.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tafel_paepste.jpg "Enlarge")

Plaque commemorating the popes buried in [St
Peter's](/wiki/St_Peter%27s_Basilica "St Peter's Basilica") (their names in
Latin and the year of their burial)

This chronological **list of[popes](/wiki/Pope "Pope")** corresponds to that
given in the _[Annuario Pontificio](/wiki/Annuario_Pontificio "Annuario
Pontificio")_ under the heading "I Sommi Pontefici Romani" (The Supreme
Pontiffs of Rome), excluding those that are explicitly indicated as
[antipopes](/wiki/Antipope "Antipope"). Published every year by the [Roman
Curia](/wiki/Roman_Curia "Roman Curia"), the _Annuario Pontificio_ attaches no
consecutive numbers to the popes, stating that it is impossible to decide
which side represented at various times the legitimate succession, in
particular regarding [Pope Leo VIII](/wiki/Pope_Leo_VIII "Pope Leo VIII"),
[Pope Benedict V](/wiki/Pope_Benedict_V "Pope Benedict V") and some mid-11th-
century popes.[1] The 2001 edition of the _Annuario Pontificio_ introduced
"almost 200 corrections to its existing biographies of the popes, from St
Peter to John Paul II". The corrections concerned dates, especially in the
first two centuries, birthplaces and the family name of one pope.[2]

The term _[pope](/wiki/Pope_\(word\) "Pope \(word\)")_ ([Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin"): _papa_ "father") is used in several Churches to denote their high
spiritual leaders (for example [Coptic
Pope](/wiki/Pope_of_the_Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria "Pope of the
Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria")). This title in English usage usually
refers to the head of the Catholic Church. The Catholic pope uses various
titles by tradition, including _[Summus Pontifex](/wiki/Summus_Pontifex
"Summus Pontifex")_ , _[Pontifex Maximus](/wiki/Pontifex_Maximus "Pontifex
Maximus")_ , and _[Servus servorum Dei](/wiki/Servus_servorum_Dei "Servus
servorum Dei")_. Each title has been added by unique historical events and
unlike other papal prerogatives, is not incapable of modification.[3]

[Hermannus Contractus](/wiki/Hermannus_Contractus "Hermannus Contractus") may
have been the first historian to number the popes continuously. His list ends
in 1049 with [Pope Leo IX](/wiki/Pope_Leo_IX "Pope Leo IX") as number 154.
Several changes were made to the list during the 20th century. [Antipope
Christopher](/wiki/Antipope_Christopher "Antipope Christopher") was considered
legitimate for a long time. [Pope-elect Stephen](/wiki/Pope-elect_Stephen
"Pope-elect Stephen") was considered legitimate under the name _Stephen II_
until the 1961 edition, when his name was erased. Although these changes are
no longer controversial, a number of modern lists still include this "first
Pope Stephen II". It is probable that this is because they are based on the
1913 edition of the _[Catholic Encyclopedia](/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia
"Catholic Encyclopedia")_ , which is in the public domain.

A significant number of these popes have been [recognized as
saints](/wiki/List_of_canonised_popes "List of canonised popes"), including 48
out of the first 50 consecutive popes, and others are in the sainthood
process. Of the first 31 popes, 28 died as martyrs (see [List of murdered
popes](/wiki/List_of_murdered_popes "List of murdered popes")).

##  Chronological list

### 1st millennium

1 | 1 April 30  
– 29 June 67  
(7004136030000000000♠37 years, 89 days) | [![1-St.Peter.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/1-St.Peter.jpg/80px-1-St.Peter.jpg)](/wiki/File:1-St.Peter.jpg) | **St[Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter "Saint Peter")**  
**PETRUS** | Šimʻōn Kêpâ  
(Simon Peter) | AD 1 [Bethsaida](/wiki/Bethsaida "Bethsaida"), [Galilea](/wiki/Galilee "Galilee"), [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") | 29 / 66 | Jew. [Apostle](/wiki/Apostle_\(Christian\) "Apostle \(Christian\)") of Jesus from whom he received the keys of the [Kingdom of Heaven](/wiki/Kingdom_of_God "Kingdom of God"), according to [Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew "Gospel of Matthew") [16:18–19](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+16%3A18%E2%80%9319&version=NRSV). Executed by crucifixion upside-down; feast day ([Feast of Saints Peter and Paul](/wiki/Feast_of_Saints_Peter_and_Paul "Feast of Saints Peter and Paul")) 29 June, ([Chair of Saint Peter](/wiki/Chair_of_Saint_Peter "Chair of Saint Peter")) 22 February. He is recognized by the Catholic Church as the first Bishop of Rome appointed by Christ. Also revered as saint in [Eastern Christianity](/wiki/Eastern_Christianity "Eastern Christianity"), with a feast day of 29 June.[4] The [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica") in Vatican City is named after him.

Papa **BENEDICTUS** Decimus Sextus | Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger | 16 April 1927 (age 90) [Marktl am Inn](/wiki/Marktl_am_Inn "Marktl am Inn"), Bavaria, [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") | 78 / 85 | Motto: _Cooperatores Veritatis_ ("Cooperators of the truth") German. Oldest to become pope since [Clement XII](/wiki/Clement_XII "Clement XII") (1730). Elevated the [Tridentine Mass](/wiki/Tridentine_Mass "Tridentine Mass") to a more prominent position and promoted the use of [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"); re-introduced several disused papal garments. Established the [Anglican Ordinariate](/wiki/Personal_ordinariate "Personal ordinariate") (2009). First pope to renounce the papacy on his own initiative since [Celestine V](/wiki/Celestine_V "Celestine V") (1294),[30] retaining regnal name with title of [Pope Emeritus](/wiki/Pope_Emeritus "Pope Emeritus").[31]

Papa **FRANCISCUS** | Jorge Mario Bergoglio, [S.J.](/wiki/Society_of_Jesus "Society of Jesus") | 17 December 1936 (age 80) [Flores, Buenos Aires](/wiki/Flores,_Buenos_Aires "Flores, Buenos Aires"), [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") | 76 / - | Motto: _Miserando atque Eligendo_ ("Lowly but chosen", literally 'by having mercy, by choosing him')[32] Italian Argentinian. First pope to be born outside Europe since [Gregory III](/wiki/Pope_Gregory_III "Pope Gregory III") (731–741) and the first from the Americas; first pope from the Southern Hemisphere. First pope from a [religious institute](/wiki/Catholic_religious_order "Catholic religious order") since [Gregory XVI](/wiki/Gregory_XVI "Gregory XVI") (1831–1846); first [Jesuit](/wiki/Society_of_Jesus "Society of Jesus") pope. First to use a new and non-composed regnal name since [Lando](/wiki/Pope_Lando "Pope Lando") (913–914).  
  
### Religious orders

38 popes have been members of [religious
orders](/wiki/Catholic_religious_order "Catholic religious order"). These have
included:

  * [Benedictines](/wiki/Benedictine "Benedictine") (18): 
    * [Gregory I](/wiki/Pope_Gregory_I "Pope Gregory I"), [Boniface IV](/wiki/Boniface_IV "Boniface IV"), [Adeodatus II](/wiki/Adeodatus_II "Adeodatus II"), [Leo IV](/wiki/Pope_Leo_IV "Pope Leo IV"), [John IX](/wiki/Pope_John_IX "Pope John IX"), [Leo VII](/wiki/Leo_VII "Leo VII"), [Sergius IV](/wiki/Sergius_IV "Sergius IV"), [Stephen IX](/wiki/Stephen_IX "Stephen IX"), [Gregory VII](/wiki/Pope_Gregory_VII "Pope Gregory VII"), [Victor III](/wiki/Victor_III "Victor III"), [Urban II](/wiki/Urban_II "Urban II"), [Paschal II](/wiki/Paschal_II "Paschal II"), [Gelasius II](/wiki/Gelasius_II "Gelasius II"), [Celestine V](/wiki/Celestine_V "Celestine V"), [Clement VI](/wiki/Clement_VI "Clement VI"), [Urban V](/wiki/Urban_V "Urban V"), [Pius VII](/wiki/Pius_VII "Pius VII")

    _and including[Camaldolese](/wiki/Camaldolese "Camaldolese") (1):_

    [Gregory XVI](/wiki/Gregory_XVI "Gregory XVI")

  * [Augustinians](/wiki/Augustinians "Augustinians") (6): 
    * [Eugene IV](/wiki/Eugene_IV "Eugene IV")

    _and including[Canons Regular](/wiki/Canons_Regular "Canons Regular") (5):_

    [Honorius II](/wiki/Honorius_II "Honorius II"), [Innocent II](/wiki/Innocent_II "Innocent II"), [Lucius II](/wiki/Lucius_II "Lucius II"), [Gregory VIII](/wiki/Gregory_VIII "Gregory VIII"), [Adrian IV](/wiki/Adrian_IV "Adrian IV")

  * [Dominicans](/wiki/Dominican_Order "Dominican Order") (5): 
    * [Innocent V](/wiki/Innocent_V "Innocent V"), [Benedict XI](/wiki/Benedict_XI "Benedict XI"), [Nicholas V](/wiki/Nicholas_V "Nicholas V"), [Pius V](/wiki/Pius_V "Pius V"), [Benedict XIII](/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XIII "Pope Benedict XIII")
  * [Franciscans](/wiki/Franciscan "Franciscan") (5): 
    * [Nicholas IV](/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_IV "Pope Nicholas IV"), [Sixtus IV](/wiki/Sixtus_IV "Sixtus IV"), [Julius II](/wiki/Julius_II "Julius II")

    _and including[Conventual Franciscans](/wiki/Conventual_Franciscans "Conventual Franciscans") (2):_

    [Sixtus V](/wiki/Sixtus_V "Sixtus V"), [Clement XIV](/wiki/Clement_XIV "Clement XIV")

  * [Cistercians](/wiki/Cistercians "Cistercians") (2): 
    * [Eugene III](/wiki/Eugene_III "Eugene III"), [Benedict XII](/wiki/Benedict_XII "Benedict XII")
  * [Theatines](/wiki/Theatines "Theatines") (1): 
    * [Paul IV](/wiki/Paul_IV "Paul IV")
  * [Jesuits](/wiki/Jesuits "Jesuits") (1): 
    * [Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis")

12 popes have been members of [third orders](/wiki/Third_order "Third order"),
also called "tertiaries" or "Third Order Secular," and all of them of the
[Secular Franciscans](/wiki/Secular_Franciscan_Order "Secular Franciscan
Order"):

  * Gregory IX, Gregory X, Martin V, Innocent XII, Clement XII, Pius IX, Leo XIII, Pius X, Benedict XV, Pius XI, Pius XII, John XXIII

## Notes on numbering of popes

A number of anomalies in the list given above need further explanation:

  * [Felix II](/wiki/Antipope_Felix_II "Antipope Felix II") (356–357), [Boniface VII](/wiki/Boniface_VII "Boniface VII") (974, 984–985), [John XVI](/wiki/Antipope_John_XVI "Antipope John XVI") (997–998), [Benedict X](/wiki/Antipope_Benedict_X "Antipope Benedict X") (1058–1059) and [Alexander V](/wiki/Antipope_Alexander_V "Antipope Alexander V") (1409–1410) are not listed because they are all considered [antipopes](/wiki/Antipope "Antipope").[33]
  * The numbering of popes named Felix has been amended to omit antipope [Felix II](/wiki/Antipope_Felix_II "Antipope Felix II"); however, most lists still call the last two Felixes [Felix III](/wiki/Pope_Felix_III "Pope Felix III") and [Felix IV](/wiki/Pope_Felix_IV "Pope Felix IV"). Additionally, there was an antipope [Felix V](/wiki/Antipope_Felix_V "Antipope Felix V").[33]
  * There has never been a pope [John XX](/wiki/Pope_John_XX "Pope John XX") as a result of [confusion of the numbering system](/wiki/Pope_John_\(numbering\) "Pope John \(numbering\)") in the 11th century.[34]
  * [Pope-elect Stephen](/wiki/Pope-elect_Stephen "Pope-elect Stephen"), who died before being consecrated, has not been on the Vatican's official list of popes since 1961, but appears on lists dating from before 1960.[34] The numbering of following popes called _Stephen_ are nowadays given as [Pope Stephen II](/wiki/Pope_Stephen_II "Pope Stephen II") (752–757) to [Pope Stephen IX](/wiki/Pope_Stephen_IX "Pope Stephen IX") (1057–1058), rather than Stephen III to Stephen X.
  * When Simon de Brion became pope in 1281, he chose to be called _Martin_. At that time, [Marinus I](/wiki/Pope_Marinus_I "Pope Marinus I") and [Marinus II](/wiki/Pope_Marinus_II "Pope Marinus II") were mistakenly considered to be Martin II and Martin III respectively, and so, erroneously, Simon de Brion became [Pope Martin IV](/wiki/Pope_Martin_IV "Pope Martin IV").[35]
  * [Pope Donus II](/wiki/Pope_Donus_II "Pope Donus II"), said to have reigned about 974, never existed. The belief resulted from the confusion of the title _dominus_ (lord) with a proper name.
  * [Pope Joan](/wiki/Pope_Joan "Pope Joan") also never existed; however, legends about her may have originated from stories about the [pornocracy](/wiki/Saeculum_obscurum "Saeculum obscurum").[36]
  * The status of [Antipope John XXIII](/wiki/Antipope_John_XXIII "Antipope John XXIII") was uncertain for hundreds of years, and was finally settled in 1958 when Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli announced his own name as John XXIII. Baldassare Cossa, who was Antipope John XXIII, served as a Cardinal of the reunited church before his death in 1419 and his remains are found in the [Florence Baptistery](/wiki/Florence_Baptistery "Florence Baptistery").
  * Those who believe in [Sedevacantism](/wiki/Sedevacantism "Sedevacantism") say that there have been no legitimate popes since Pius XII. This is because they consider all popes since the [Second Vatican Council](/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council "Second Vatican Council") to be [heretics](/wiki/Heretic "Heretic").[37][38]
